content.content:
## Talk track (fast)

- Lead with **reliability** and **product protection** (downtime costs money)
- Controls-first: floating head, suction optimization, demand defrost
- Hardware quick wins: door gaskets, strip curtains, ECM fan motors, anti-sweat controls
- Big levers: case doors for open cases, system upgrades when refrigerant/regulation drives replacement

**One-liner:** "We lower energy cost and reduce risk of spoilage‚Äîoften starting with controls and simple field fixes."

## What to verify (fast)

- Baseline head pressure control strategy (fixed vs floating)
- Suction setpoints and stability
- Defrost: schedule vs demand, termination controls
- Anti-sweat controls and fan motor types
- Monitoring/trending available (temps, pressures, alarms)

**Rule:** validate product temp requirements first, then optimize head/suction and defrost to reduce compressor work.

## What to capture on-site

- Equipment nameplates: compressors, condensers, evaporators
- Refrigerant type and charge notes (if known)
- Door condition: gaskets, closers, strip curtains
- Frost/ice evidence and drain condition
- Controller screenshots: head pressure, suction, defrost schedule
- Fan motors: PSC vs ECM and anti-sweat heater controls

sections.title: Introduction & Fundamentals
sections.subtitle: Commercial refrigeration is a controls + maintenance game

content.content:
# Why Refrigeration Matters

Refrigeration is a critical end-use for grocery, restaurants, cold storage, and some process facilities. Savings levers are often **controls and operational tuning** plus targeted hardware upgrades.

Key idea: refrigeration energy is driven by **temperature lift** and by **infiltration/defrost** that adds load.

- Reduce compressor work by lowering head pressure and optimizing suction
- Reduce load by improving doors, gaskets, and defrost control
- Improve persistence with monitoring and alarms

- Display cases (medium temp) and freezers (low temp)
- Large rack systems and controls
- High savings from case doors, anti-sweat control, floating head

- Walk-ins and reach-ins

sections.title: Walk-in Coolers & Freezers
sections.subtitle: Loads, components, and common efficiency issues

content.content:
## Walk-in energy drivers

- Infiltration through doors and openings
- Heat gain through walls/ceilings/floor (insulation condition)
- Evaporator fan energy
- Defrost energy (especially low-temp)

Common issues:
- Damaged door gaskets and misaligned doors
- Missing strip curtains
- Ice buildup from warm air infiltration
- Poor drain management

**Field tip:** a warm door frame or heavy frost is usually a leak or control issue.

sections.title: Display Cases
sections.subtitle: Open vs door cases, anti-sweat, and airflow

content.content:
## Display case basics

Open cases increase infiltration and refrigeration load. Adding doors or covers can dramatically reduce load and improve aisle comfort.

Other levers:
- **Anti-sweat heater control** (based on humidity)
- ECM fan motors
- Night curtains (where acceptable)

**Sales translation:** case doors are a high-visibility upgrade that saves energy and improves comfort.

rows: Use humidity-based control to avoid over-heating
Cuts fan kWh and improves part-load performance

content.content:
## Refrigerants: why it matters

- High-GWP refrigerants face regulatory pressure and higher lifecycle cost risk
- Refrigerant leaks create large climate impact and can be costly

### Practical guidance
- Track refrigerant type, charge size, and leak history
- Consider compliance timelines and serviceability
- Evaluate retrofit vs replacement based on system age and risk

**Sales translation:** refrigerant compliance is a forcing function‚Äîcombine compliance projects with efficiency upgrades.

## Compressor power basics

Compressor power rises with:
- Higher lift (higher head pressure or lower suction)
- Higher mass flow (higher load)

Condenser performance matters:
- Clean coils
- Proper fan staging/VFD
- Correct head pressure controls

**Field tip:** dirty condensers and failed fans force high head pressure and spike kW.

sections.title: Floating Head Pressure
sections.subtitle: A top control lever for refrigeration energy

content.content:
## What floating head does

Floating head pressure reduces condensing pressure when outdoor ambient allows.

Benefits:
- Lower compressor lift ‚Üí lower kW
- Often easy to implement if controls support it

Watch-outs:
- Too-low head can impact expansion valve behavior and oil return if not designed
- Must coordinate with condenser fan control

**Sales translation:** it‚Äôs a ‚Äúcontrols-first‚Äù measure with big savings potential.

items: Confirm controller supports floating head strategy
Set minimum head pressure limits by manufacturer guidance

content.content:
## Why defrost is a hidden load

Defrost energy is paid twice:
- Direct defrost energy (electric or hot gas)
- Extra refrigeration to remove the added heat after defrost

### Better approaches
- Demand defrost (terminate based on coil condition)
- Proper termination and fan delay
- Reduce infiltration so frost accumulates slower

**Field tip:** if coils are defrosting when not frosted, there‚Äôs a control opportunity.

sections.title: Doors, Gaskets & Strip Curtains
sections.subtitle: Behavior and maintenance that saves energy

content.content:
## Door-related measures

- Replace worn gaskets
- Fix door alignment and closers
- Add/repair strip curtains
- Reduce door-open time (training + signage)

Benefits:
- Lower infiltration ‚Üí lower compressor load
- Reduced frost ‚Üí less defrost energy
- Improved temperature stability

**Sales translation:** low-cost maintenance fixes can yield surprising savings and improve reliability.

## Why monitoring matters

Refrigeration savings and reliability persist when you can detect:
- Drifting setpoints
- Door failures and infiltration events
- Defrost issues
- Compressor/condenser faults

Even basic monitoring (temps + alarms) protects product and reduces emergency calls.

**Sales translation:** monitoring is a risk-reduction product as much as an energy saver.

# Selling Refrigeration Projects

## The framing

- **Reliability and product protection** first
- Then energy savings (often large and persistent)

### Discovery questions
- Any recent spoilage incidents or warm temperature alarms?
- Do you have monitoring today? Who responds to alarms?
- How often do you see frost/ice buildup?
- Are case doors/covers feasible operationally?
- What refrigerant is in use and what is the leak history?

### Objection handling
| Objection | Response |
|---|---|
| "We can‚Äôt change operations" | "Start with controls (floating head, defrost) and maintenance fixes‚Äîminimal behavior change." |
| "We‚Äôre worried about product temps" | "We trend temps during adjustments and keep conservative limits‚Äîproduct protection is the priority." |
| "We‚Äôll replace later" | "Controls and low-cost fixes reduce energy and risk now‚Äîand can improve performance until replacement." |

sections.subtitle: What to capture in a refrigeration walkdown

items: Photograph controllers and setpoints (suction, head, defrost schedule)
Record refrigerant type if visible on labels/service docs
Document door condition (gaskets, closers, strip curtains) and any infiltration signs
Note frost/ice on coils and drain condition
Capture condenser coil condition and fan operation
List case types (open vs doors) and anti-sweat heater control method
Ask about alarm response process and service history

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of floating head pressure control?
options: Lower compressor lift and kW when ambient allows
Raise suction pressure to unsafe levels
questions.explanation: Floating head reduces condensing pressure in cool ambient conditions, lowering compressor lift and energy.

questions.question: Why do door gaskets and strip curtains save energy in walk-ins?
options: They reduce warm air infiltration and frost load
questions.explanation: Reducing infiltration lowers refrigeration load and reduces frost accumulation and defrost energy.

questions.question: Why can over-defrosting increase energy use?
options: It adds heat that must be removed afterward
questions.explanation: Defrost adds heat directly and then the refrigeration system must remove that added heat.

questions.question: Which upgrade often provides a major load reduction for open refrigerated display cases?
questions.explanation: Doors/covers reduce infiltration and refrigeration load significantly.

questions.question: What is a key non-energy driver for refrigeration projects?
questions.explanation: Reliability and protecting product from temperature excursions is often the primary business driver.
